diets.name: Pegan diet
do: Vegetables, mostly those that have low starch or rank low on the glycemic index, such as broccoli, carrots, peas, and tomatoes
Nuts like almonds, pistachios, and walnuts
Seeds such as chia, flax, and pumpkin
Grass-fed meats like beef, chicken, and pork
Fish high in fats and low in mercury, like salmon, herring, and cod
Gluten-free grains (now and then) like quinoa, brown rice, oats, and amaranth
donot: Bread, pasta, baked goods, cereals, granola, and beer
Anything with preservatives or artificial colors, flavors, or sweeteners

diets.name: Gluten free diet
do: Beans, seeds, legumes and nuts in their natural, unprocessed forms
Lean, nonprocessed meats, fish and poultry
Gluten-free grains (now and then) like quinoa, brown rice, oats, and amaranth
donot: Beer, ale, porter, stout (usually contain barley)
Seasoned snack foods, such as potato and tortilla chips

diets.name: Francese diet
do: Fruit, vegetables, legumes (e.g. lentils and beans), nuts and whole grains (e.g. unprocessed maize, millet, oats, wheat and brown rice).
At least 400 g (i.e. five portions) of fruit and vegetables per day (2), excluding potatoes, sweet potatoes, cassava and other starchy roots.
Less than 5  g of salt (equivalent to about one teaspoon) per day (8).  Salt should be iodized.

Less than 10% of total energy intake from free sugars (2, 7), which is equivalent to 50 g (or about 12 level teaspoons) for a person of healthy body weight consuming about 2000 calories per day, but ideally is less than 5% of total energy intake for additional health benefits (7). Free sugars are all sugars added to foods or drinks by the manufacturer, cook or consumer, as well as sugars naturally present in honey, syrups, fruit juices and fruit juice concentrates.

Less than 30% of total energy intake from fats (1, 2, 3). Unsaturated fats (found in fish, avocado and nuts, and in sunflower, soybean, canola and olive oils) are preferable to saturated fats (found in fatty meat, butter, palm and coconut oil, cream, cheese, ghee and lard) and trans-fats of all kinds, including both industrially-produced trans-fats (found in baked and fried foods, and pre-packaged snacks and foods, such as frozen pizza, pies, cookies, biscuits, wafers, and cooking oils and spreads) and ruminant trans-fats (found in meat and dairy foods from ruminant animals, such as cows, sheep, goats and camels).

diets.name: Intermittent fasting
do: Fruit, vegetables, legumes (e.g. lentils and beans), nuts and whole grains (e.g. unprocessed maize, millet, oats, wheat and brown rice).
At least 400 g (i.e. five portions) of fruit and vegetables per day (2), excluding potatoes, sweet potatoes, cassava and other starchy roots.
Less than 5  g of salt (equivalent to about one teaspoon) per day (8).  Salt should be iodized.

Less than 10% of total energy intake from free sugars (2, 7), which is equivalent to 50 g (or about 12 level teaspoons) for a person of healthy body weight consuming about 2000 calories per day, but ideally is less than 5% of total energy intake for additional health benefits (7). Free sugars are all sugars added to foods or drinks by the manufacturer, cook or consumer, as well as sugars naturally present in honey, syrups, fruit juices and fruit juice concentrates.

Less than 30% of total energy intake from fats (1, 2, 3). Unsaturated fats (found in fish, avocado and nuts, and in sunflower, soybean, canola and olive oils) are preferable to saturated fats (found in fatty meat, butter, palm and coconut oil, cream, cheese, ghee and lard) and trans-fats of all kinds, including both industrially-produced trans-fats (found in baked and fried foods, and pre-packaged snacks and foods, such as frozen pizza, pies, cookies, biscuits, wafers, and cooking oils and spreads) and ruminant trans-fats (found in meat and dairy foods from ruminant animals, such as cows, sheep, goats and camels).

diets.name: Mediterranean Diet
do: Whole grains(oats, brown rice, rye, barley, corn)
Most low-fat dairy products(cheese, yogurt, milk)
Herbs and spices(garlic, basil, mint, rosemary, sage, nutmeg, cinnamon, pepper)
donot: Added sugar(soda, candies, ice cream, table sugar, syrup, and baked goods)
Refined grains(white bread, pasta, tortillas, chips, crackers)
Trans fats(margarine, fried foods, and other processed foods)
Processed meat(processed sausages, hot dogs, deli meats, beef jerkys)
Refined oils(soybean oil, canola oil, cottonseed oil, grapeseed oil)
Highly processed foods(fast food, convenience meals, microwave popcorn, granola bars)

diets.name: Pescatarian Diet
do: Fresh fish (salmon, cod, sardines, pollock, and catfish)
Fresh shellfish (clams, crab, oysters, shrimp, and scallops)
Canned shellfish (clams, crab, oysters, shrimp, and scallops)
Frozen seafood (fish sticks, salmon, trout, herring, and shrimp)
Legumes (including kidney beans, peas, and pinto beans)
Cereals and whole grains (including corn, rice, oats, bulgar wheat, and amaranth)
Gluten-free pseudo grains (such as buckwheat and quinoa)
Seeds, such as flaxseeds, hemp seeds, and chia

diets.name: MIND Diet
do: Green, leafy vegetables(kale, spinach, cooked greens, and salads)
Whole grains(oatmeal, quinoa, brown rice, whole wheat pasta, 100% whole wheat bread)
donot: Pastries and sweets(ice cream, cookies, brownies, snack cakes, doughnuts, candy)

diets.name: Dr. Weilâ€™s Anti-Inflammatory Diet
do: Dark, leafy greens such as spinach or kale
Cruciferous vegetables such as cabbage and broccoli
Whole grains, such as brown rice and quinoa
donot: foods with added sugar or salt)

diets.name: Ornish Diet
do: Whole grains, like brown rice and whole wheat
donot: foods with added sugar or salt)

diets.name: Paleo Diet
do: Lean meats, especially grass-fed animals or wild game
Oils from fruits and nuts, such as olive oil or walnut oil
donot: Starchy vegetables(corn, jicama, peas and white potatoes)

diets.name: Keto Diet
do: Fish and Seafood(Salmon, sardines, mackerel, albacore tuna)
Low-Carb Veggies(Broccoli, cauliflower, green beans, bell peppers, zucchini, spinach)
Plain Greek Yogurt and Cottage Cheese
Nuts, Seeds and Healthy Oils(Almonds, Brazil nuts, Cashews, Pecans, Pistachios, Chia seeds)
donot: Honey, syrup or sugar in any form
Baked goods including gluten-free baked goods

diets.name: Sirtfood Diet
donot: fats other than extra-virgin olive oil
fish that are high in mercury

diets.name: Intermittent fasting
do: The rules for this diet are simple. A person needs to decide on and adhere to a 12-hour fasting window every day.
Fasting for 16 hours a day, leaving an eating window of 8 hours, is called the 16:8 method or the Leangains diet.
People following the 5:2 diet eat standard amounts of healthful food for 5 days and reduce calorie intake on the other 2 days.

For some people, alternate day fasting means a complete avoidance of solid foods on fasting days, while other people allow up to 500 calories. On feeding days, people often choose to eat as much as they want.

The Warrior Diet involves eating very little, usually just a few servings of raw fruit and vegetables, during a 20-hourTrusted Source fasting window, then eating one large meal at night. The eating window is usually only around 4 hours.
